Situation1: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Situation2: They encounter a situation where a friend is being treated unfairly and feel a stronger responsibility to intervene or speak up.
Story: As I scanned the pool from my lifeguard chair, my whistle ready, I noticed a group of kids slipping into the shallow end without an adult nearby. The rules were clear—no unsupervised swimming. I was supposed to enforce them, no exceptions. But then, out of the corner of my eye, I saw my friend Ravi at the snack bar, his face flushed with embarrassment as another staff member scolded him loudly for a mistake he didn’t make. My heart twisted. As a Hindu, I was taught to stand up for dharma, to act with compassion and fairness. I felt a deep urge to go to Ravi, to speak up for him, to make sure he wasn’t humiliated for something he didn’t do. But my duty as a lifeguard pulled me back—if I left my post, even for a moment, I’d be breaking the trust placed in me to keep everyone safe. The weight of both responsibilities pressed on me, each demanding my immediate attention, and I felt torn, unable to ignore either call.
